Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2010 05:31AM sunnydaze wrote: I am on Cytoxan and Taxotere and have what I can only describe as bone crushing pain after every treatment.  Just finished my third round.  Like you, I've done lots of research on this and I don't think there's any way around it but to manage with the pain meds and flush the system with as much water and other fluids as possible.  Worst days for me are 3-7 and it is debilitating, even with narcotics.  I have vicodin and dilaudid (for the worst days) for pain management and even on the worst days I'm still miserable. I also go completely neutropenic between sessions- which doesn't help - because I have to do the neupogen shots, which also cause, as you probably know, intense bone pain.  Better than ending up in the hospital with neutropenia and strep though (that happened after my first round).     Big hug to you - you are not alone!  I didn't see how many tx's of the taxotere you have left?  Stay on top of your pain meds... it will subside - though never completely.  I have to take narcotics almost every day between sessions just to be able to live.  If it doesn't subside enough for you there is a pain patch called fentanyl or phentanyl you can get. I have a friend on this and she said it changed her life.  I can still manage with the pills so my doc wants me to try to do continue that since I am nearing the end of my treatment.  But if it were going to go on much longer I would def request those patches. Take care of yourself.  xoxoxo
Posts.Title: Crazy Bone Pain - started Taxotere and Rads last week LivingIt sunnydaze

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2010 09:51PM sunnydaze wrote: Odinsmom - I had bilateral mastectomy... for BRCA1 status and for reconstruction purposes I decided to go for the full monty. Reconstruction planned for after chemo.  I wanted everything to be the same when I'm finished. I don't know if there was any especially skin sparing technique used on me.  I do know that in comparison to my mom's mastectomy it looks like I have quite a bit more skin left than she did.  And I am certain today that I will not go back to Ds.  This feels really good.  I am a runner and have always had to have a lot of support for "the girls" and could never wear the cute tank tops that leaner girls could wear - well, i could wear them but might likely be arrested.  :) Soooo... here we go... Sunny 2.0.   Pain virtually gone except for right side where they took the nodes.  I am showering and even prepared my own lunch today. Only took 3 vicodin today versus 7 yesterday...  these are good things! I'm ready to heal up and start chemo and be done with this stuff.
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 11:13PM sunnydaze wrote: Hi girls.... better late than never.  Here I am... BMX scheduled July 14... 5 days and a wake up... lots to do yet to prepare but I've gotten a lot done this week.  Feels almost like nesting... for a baby... except without getting the baby.  Ha!   I'm in pretty good spirits... kinda getting used to the idea of losing the tah-tahs, for saving my life.  :) Anyway - thought I would introduce myself. I'm 37 yrs old... newly single mom (actually still not officially divorced but close enough for me)... have two boys ages 3 and 4.  Just moved us all into my parents' place so they can help me with the kiddos while I do this cancer thing. Tonight I feel oddly at peace with it all.  Which is strange because I'm typically PI$$ED about the whole deal.  lol Time to put our rally caps on and go kick some butt! Love this board to pieces... thank goodness we're in this together.
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2010 04:01PM sunnydaze wrote: and PS - just took my first shower post mastectomy - i am actually quite pleased with the results.. not nearly as hideous and i thought i would be AND they left what I consider to be a good amount of skin.. I almost still have cleavage.  :)  should make for a good reconstruction down the road .. and now that I am sitting here boob-free, without my D's... I maybe considering going smaller next time around.  I kind of like the free feeling!  Hope everyone's recover is going well... mine seems to be.  :)  Although the pain meds are interferring with my typing and spelling skills.  lol

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 12:42PM sunnydaze wrote: calamtykel - is your real name Kelly?  Mine is too!  And seriously - I never imagined liking this feeling of being breastless... I was prepared for exactly the opposite.  i am going to cruise the reconstruction boards and see if anyone went smaller.  I have recently lost 30 lbs after my ex walked out on us... got in shape, running and weight training... so maybe I don't need D's anymore... I would be totally satisfied if I could just look healthy and proportionate. pm me anytime!

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2010 05:42PM sunnydaze wrote: Peppercook - good luck to you and remember this - even if the panic sets in tonight - tell the nurses right when you get there that you are feeling quite anxious - they WILL give you something to mellow you out for the rest of the time before your procedure.  Also if its not too late you can call your surgeon's office and get a prescription for valium or ativan tonight!  Mine had no problem giving it to me. See you on the flip side... I'm 5 days out and doing well (but didn't do immed recon like you)... hang in there you'll be great!  and check in with us when you're back on the grid and let us know how you're doing.  We're here for you.
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2010 12:43PM sunnydaze wrote: Hi girls,... checking in post surgery on 7/14 The hospital staff - all of the - were AMAZING.  Which really really helped.  I had several conversation with different staff... as most of you were probably sent for mapping of sentinal nodes prior to your surgery... radiologist there was BRCA1 - had already had ovaries removed... said she sees people like me come through her office for pre-surgery imaging almost daily.  She is consider profolactic mastectomy. My night nurse was an ANGEL - kept me on the iv dilotted since she took over around 8 pm to 8am.   Vicodin sucks and I will be off the stuff as soon as I can tolerate the pain.  I have virtually no pain on the left side... just have pain on right where they took nodes.  And that pain is about a 5. Path report not back yet but surgeon said nodes looked and felt normal - so I am cautiously optimistic we're in good shape there. That's about all I got - too dopey to write more.  I'll check in later. Love you all!  This surgery was not that bad -at least for me.  So if you haven't gone yet, don't be scared.
